occurrences.line_text: But when he saw his foe before in vew,
Long shut vp in the bud from heauens vew,
Which sorie sight when Calidore did vew
Tho whenas he approched nigh in vew,
Was much emmoued at his perils vew,
Whom soone as his three enemies did vew,
And with his teeth and nailes, in present vew,
Therefore so soone as he was out of vew,
But loe the Gods, that mortall follies vew,
Fly like a flocke of doues before a Faulcons vew.
Were downe to them descended in that earthly vew.
And also of the obiect of his vew,
Another quest, another game in vew
Like to one sight, which Calidore did vew?
But soone as he appeared to their vew,
One day as he did all his prisoners vew,
Some vprore were like that, which lately she did vew.
For on her brest I with these eyes did vew
Her selfe a while therein she vewd in vaine;
Tho hauing vewd a while the surges hore,
And though oft looking backward, well she vewd,
At night, when all they went to sleepe, he vewd,
The noble Mayd, still standing all this vewd,
Hauing by chaunce a close aduantage vew'd,
Backe to the place, whereas his Lord he sleeping vew'd.
Those villeins vew'd with loose lasciuious sight,
Wherein her face she often vewed fayne,
But when they vewed haue her heauenly grace,
He gan himselfe to vaunt: but when he vewed
Who hauing vewed in a fountaine shere
So straungely vewed her straunge louers shade,
So closely yet, that none but she it vewed,
But soone as th'other nigh approaching, vewed
And her gan cheare, with what she there had vewed,
Whom Calidore a while well hauing vewed,
Her whyles Sir Calidore there vewed well,
High on an hill, his flocke to vewen wide,
The God himselfe vewing that mirrhour rare,
And oft his mother vewing his wide wound,
She it surrendred, ne her selfe would lenger vex.
And with vaine thoughts her falsed fancy vex:
Did him attonce oppresse, and vex his caytiue spright.
Wherewith imperious loue her hart did vexe,
Of his hard hap did vexe his noble brest,
Him calling theefe, them whores; that much did vexe
But day and night did vexe her carefull thought,
And vexeth so, that makes her eat her gall.
Them sorely vext, and courst, and ouerran,
In mischiefe: for her selfe she onely vext;
Of liuing bloud yet in her veynes did hop;
A monstrous Dragon, full of fearefull vglinesse.
By which he saw the vgly monster plaine,
Such vgly monstrous shapes elswhere may no man reed.
And with foule vgly forme did her disgrace:
But this same Monster much more vgly was;
More vgly shape yet neuer liuing creature saw.
The vgly vew of his deformed crimes,
And horribly misshapes with vgly sightes,
And Shame his vgly face did hide from liuing eye.
An vgly feend, more fowle then dismall day,
And vgly shapes did nigh the man dismay,
So fowle and vgly, that exceeding feare
For by those vgly formes weren pourtrayd,
And some like vgly Vrchins thicke and short:
Most vgly shapes, and horrible aspects,
That vgly shape so sore her terrifide,
Let vgly shame and endlesse infamy
This vgly creature in his armes her snatcht,
Much more deformed fearefull vgly were,
And but halfe seene his vgly visnomie,
With vgly craples crawling in their way,
So vgly creature, she was nigh dismayd,
Whose vgly shape none euer saw, nor kend,
Most vgly filth, and poyson therewith rusht,
His face was vgly, and his countenance sterne,
Did much the more augment, and made most vgly cases.
Her face was vgly, and her mouth distort,
Seeing the vgly Monster passing by,
An angry Waspe th'one in a viall had
The whiles the viandes in the vessell boyld
Against the viaundes should be ministred.
And she that vertue loues and vice detests
Is now cald vice; and that which vice was hight,
Is now cald vice; and that which vice was hight,
Yet then likewise the wicked seede of vice
Both those the lawrell girlonds to the victor dew.
And clapt his yron wings, as victor he did dwell.
And that he victor onely did remaine;
Vnto the Victor of the Gods this bee:
Till like a victor on his backe he ride,
Yet whether side was victor, note be ghest:
Fled fast into the towne, and her sole victor left.
Had vow'd vnto the victor, him to trace
Saint George of mery England, the signe of victoree.
Gaynd in Nemea goodly victoree;
But when the victoresse arriued there,
Approcht in hast to greet his victorie,
Greeting him goodly with new victorie,
Came running fast to greet his victorie,
But when thou famous victorie hast wonne,
Of their new ioy, and happie victorie
Glad signe of victorie and peace in all their land.
The king returned proud of victorie,
And with rich spoiles and famous victorie,
And th'vtmost meanes of victorie assay,
Then honour was the meed of victorie,
And if he then with victorie can lin,
And gan thereat to triumph without victorie.
In doubt to whom she victorie should deeme,
Ne desperate of glorious victorie,
A signe which did to him the victorie assure.
And each to other seemd the victorie to yield.
For though that he first victorie obtayned,
Ne any left, that victorie to him enuide.
Yet vertue vauntes in both their victories,
In Henault, where yet of his victories
Faire Lady, then said that victorious knight,
To see the face of that victorious man:
Whom his victorious hands did earst restore
The saluage beastes in her victorious play,
Till this mad man, whom your victorious might
He them defeated in victorious fight,
As well in that same field victorious
In hope thereof to win victorious spoile.
And his proud foes discomfit in victorious field.
Beside Cayr Verolame, in victorious fight,
The bold Bunduca, whose victorious
And pledges; as the spoiles of my victorious games.
Which raignd so many yeares victorious,
Cannot employ your most victorious speare
With warlike spoiles, and with victorious prayes,
By her subdewed in victorious fray:
At last from his victorious shield he drew
That your victorious arme will not yet cease,
As their victorious deedes haue often showen,
To range the field, and victorlike to raine,
A Rosy girlond was the victors meede:
From raging spoile of lawlesse victors will?
Of victors glory from him snatcht away:
Whilest here thy shield is hangd for victors hyre,
I will him reaue of armes, the victors hire,
The worlds reproch, the cruell victors scorne,
The vassall of the victors will byliue:
To shew the victors might and mercilesse intent.
Lo sluggish Knight the victors happie pray:
Yet victors both them selues alwayes esteemed.
That whylome wont to be the victors meed;
And much repynd, that both of victors meede,
Was made the vassall of the victors might;
Left in the victors powre, like vassall bond;
But fortune now the victors meed did make;
Forgetfull of the hanging victory:
To muse on meanes of hoped victory.
That victory they dare not wish to either side.
That thorough grace hath gained victory.
most glorious victory.
Vaine is the vaunt, and victory vniust,
The present offer of faire victory.
Does yeeld vnto his foe a pleasant victory.
Gaue him great hart, and hope of victory.
So by him Caesar got the victory,
Of his successe and gladfull victory:
Ne how to win the wished victory,
Signe of nigh battell, or got victory;
To whether should the victory befall,
And gaue his foe good hope of victory.
A garland was the meed of victory.
From her left arme, to rest in glorious victorye.
But to the mighty victour yields a bounteous feast.
Then on his brest his victour foote he thrust:
His forlorne steed from him the victour wan;
He with his victour sword first opened,
And with fresh courage on the victour seru'd:
Which as a victour proud, gan ransack fast
And meekely stoup vnto the victour strong:
Yet dared not his victour to withstand,
The riuall slaine, the victour through the flood
Yet after all, he victour did suruiue,
And of them all the victour should his sister take.
For that he sau'd the victour from fordonne:
For Cambell victour was in all mens sight,
The Saluage Knight, that victour was whileare,
And there the Prince, as victour of that day,
And yields it selfe vnto the victours might;
And yeeldes his caytiue neck to victours most despight.
Both loosers lot, and victours prayse alsoe.
So he now subiect to the victours law,
So made them victours, whom he did subdew.
In their auenge, tread downe the victours surquedry.
To saue his people sad from victours vengefull hands.
More busying his quicke eyes, her face to view,
Could not endure th'vnwonted sunne to view;
And sad to view his visage pale and wan,
Such whenas Archimago them did view,
Pitifull spectacle, as euer eye did view.
To serue at court in view of vaunting eye;
Farre from the view of Gods and heauens blis,
To view and deeme the deedes of armes that day;
His wondrous worth declared in all mens view.
Then first Cambello brought vnto their view
By view of all the fairest to him brought,
That them to view had bene an vncouth sight;
To view the thrals, which there in bondage lay:
To view the building of that vncouth place,
As well by view of that his vestiment,
From view of men, and wicked worlds disdaine.
Which as they view with lustfull fantasyes,
From view of liuing wight, and couered ouer:
And darkenesse dredd, that neuer viewed day,
Her loathly visage viewing with disdaine,
What mote they be: who viewing them more neare
But Peridure and Vigent him disthronized.
With vigilant regard, and dew attent,
Which did not them preuent with vigilant foresight.
Yet liuely vigour rested in his mind,
Through that rings vertue, that with vigour new,
Her goodly port, and to their senses vild,
To be her thrall, his fellow seruant vild;
To saue her honor from that villaine vild,
And made the vassall of his pleasures vilde.
And sold thy selfe to serue Duessa vilde,
He comming present, where the Monster vilde
Bidding her feare no more her foeman vilde,
Regardlesse of that queane so base and vilde,
On that vilde man, and all his family.
Of that vilde race, and stablished my peace.
And saw those villaines her so vildely vse,
Which stunck so vildly, that it forst him slacke
Her vildly entertaines, and will or nill,
And raise my thoughts too humble and too vile,
A monster vile, whom God and man does hate:
Most lothsom, filthie, foule, and full of vile disdaine.
Now a loose Leman to vile seruice bound:
And her due loues deriu'd to that vile witches share.
A vile disease, and eke in foote and hand
Such one vile Enuie was, that fift in row did sitt.
Is there possessed of the traytour vile,
Ne wicked enuie, ne vile gealosy
When that lewd ribauld with vile lust aduaunst
To come, where vile Acrasia does wonne,
Which when the vile Enchaunteresse perceiu'd,
Vile Caytiue, vassall of dread and despaire,
In foule reproch, and termes of vile despight,
Who glad t'embosome his affection vile,
He wexed wondrous wroth, and said, Vile knight,
The vile Acrasia, that with vaine delightes,
Vile Miscreant (said he) whither doest thou flie
And their vile carcases now left vnburied.
With such vaine shewes thy worldlings vile abuse:
That sire he foule bespake, Thou dotard vile,
Vile is the vengeance on the ashes cold,
Of vile reuenge. To spoile the dead of weed
On this vile bodie from to wreake my wrong,
For vile disdaine and rancour, which did gnaw
Vile caytiue wretches, ragged, rude, deformd,
Would not endure to be so vile disdaind,
For thy, this hight The Rocke of vile Reproch,
That now he chooseth, with vile difference,
Vile rancour to auoid, and cruell surquedrie.
Abhorred bloudshed, and vile felony,
Vile rancour their rude harts had fild with such despight.
And that vile Hag, all were her whole delight
Of that vile hag, or her vnciuile sonne:
Or be the vassall of her pleasures vile,
Of vile vngentlenesse, or hospitages breach.
And that vile knight, who euer that he bee,
Vntroubled of vile feare, or bitter fell.
Of that Argante vile and vitious,
Yet thou vile man, vile Scudamore art sound,
Yet thou vile man, vile Scudamore art sound,
And for her sake a cowheard vile became,
The seruant of Admetus cowheard vile,
Vile Pouertie, and lastly Death with infamie.
And her before the vile Enchaunter sate,
To giue him the reward for such vile outrage dew.
For so huge mischiefe, and vile villany
For that same vile Enchauntour Busyran,
Vile treason and fowle falshood hidden were,
So false Duessa, but vile Ate thus;
Vile hag (sayd Scudamour) why dost thou lye?
Which he to shun, and stop vile enuies sting,
And how from thraldome vile they were vntide
But voide of vile and treacherous intent,
And with vile curses, and reprochfull shame
With bitter taunts, and termes of vile disgrace.
His mightie hands, the distaffe vile to hold,
For to auenge, full many treasons vile
These vile reproches gan vnto her speake;
And her late vile reproch, though vaunted vaine,
But blotted with condition vile and base,
She with the sting, which in her vile tongue grew,
Whom with vile tongue and venemous intent
Vile recreant, know that I doe much disdaine
And greedy to auenge that vile despight,
From that vile lozell, which her late offended,
Of all the vile demeane, and vsage bad,
Art thou he, traytor, that with treason vile,
Vile cowheard dogge, now doe I much repent,
Be arguments of a vile donghill mind;
His foot he set on his vile necke, in signe
With his vile tongue, which many had defamed,
At last he thus; Thou clod of vilest clay,
Of all the passions in the mind thou vilest art.
And vassall to the vilest wretch aliue,
Tho when that villain he auiz'd, which late
To saue her honor from that villaine vild,
Loe where the villaine selfe, their sorrowes sourse,
Thereto the villaine vsed craft in fight;
A villaine to them came with scull all raw,
To weet a wicked villaine, bold and stout,
Eftsoones brought forth the villaine, as they ment,
But when the villaine saw her so affrayd,
So did the villaine to her prate and play,
For to pursue that villaine, which had reft
And running streight vpon that villaine base,
But most the former villaine, which did lead
The villaine, wroth for greeting him so sore,
The villaine stayd not aunswer to inuent,
The villaine met him in the middle fall,
The whiles that other villaine went about
The villaine leauing him vnto his mate
And who he was, and what those villaines were,
She fell into that saluage villaines hand,
And saw those villaines her so vildely vse,
Vnder that villaines club, then surely thought
Beheld two such, of two such villaines thrall,
That in that villaines health her safety lies:
Whether I shall you leaue, or from these villaines lose.
Vnto the rocke, where was the villains won:
And now he hath this troupe of villains sent,
And eke defiled with foule villanie
And armes dishonour with base villanie,
For his late villanies.
And to haue wrought vnwares some villanous assay.
To reskew her from shamefull villany.
For so huge mischiefe, and vile villany
For horrour of his shamefull villany.
And vnto them wrought all the villany,
With full intent t'auenge that villany,
And saued from his cruell villany.
For cowardize doth still in villany delight.
Of villany to be to her inferd:
And to the villein said, Thou damned wight,
Then gan the villein him to ouercraw,
And being downe the villein sore did beat,
Where this same wicked villein did me light vpon.
Tho gan that villein wex so fiers and strong,
A sturdy villein, striding stiffe and bold,
For nothing might abash the villein bold,
And in his flight the villein turn'd his face,
Till that the villein comming to their ayd,
When suddein vp the villein ouerthrowne,
Yet she no lesse the knight feard, then that villein rude.
Villein (said he) this Ladie is my deare,
The greedy villein from his hoped pray,
With so fell force and villeinous despighte,
But thou doest weene with villeinous despight,
The which he thought, for villeinous despight,
Yet so exceeding was the villeins powre,
A thousand villeins round about them swarmd
That wicked band of villeins fresh begon
Led of two grysie villeins, th'one Despight,
And those two villeins, which her steps vpstayd,
Eftsoones one of those villeins him did rap
To vnderstand that villeins dwelling place,
Those villeins vew'd with loose lasciuious sight,
We met that villen (God from him me blesse)
Nathlesse the villen sped him selfe so well,
That can her best defend from villenie;
And euermore from villenie her kept:
The Prince much mused at such villenie,
Would not be tempted to such villenie,
And him auenge of that so villenous despight.
Willing to worke his villenous intent
But that those villens through their vsage bad
To haue reuenged that his villeny;
Withouten thought of shame or villeny,
Where he mote worke him scath and villeny.
In greene vine leaues he was right fitly clad;
Ouer the which was cast a wandring vine,
Archt ouer head with an embracing vine,
He turnd himselfe into a fruitfull vine,
The fruitfull vine, whose liquor blouddy red
The vine-prop Elme, the Poplar neuer dry,
Their tender buds or leaues to violate,
That beautie durst presume to violate,
Did faire auoide the violence him nere;
That almost it did haynous violence
That broke the violence of his intent,
Them to efforce by violence or wrong;
This land inuaded with like violence,
And in strong banckes his violence enclose,
Of strong compulsion, and streight violence,
To reskue her from their rude violence,
His violence in vaine, and with his spere
And did from further violence restraine,
Or by some other violence despoyled.
With cruell rage and dreadfull violence
That th'outrage of his violence he stayd,
But two then all more huge and violent,
Where streame more violent and greedy growes:
Did afterwards make shipwracke violent,
And strooke at him with force so violent,
But with such force and furie violent,
Breakes forth, and makes his way more violent.
But still his passion grew more violent and strong.
The cup to ground did violently cast,
And fragrant violets, and Pances trim,
She bath'd with roses red, and violets blew,
Bransles, Ballads, virelayes, and verses vaine;
Helpe then, O holy Virgin chiefe of nine,
Most like that virgin true, which for her knight him took.
The royall virgin shooke off drowsy-hed,
A virgin widow, whose deepe wounded mind
Soone as the royall virgin he did spy,
Arose the virgin borne of heauenly brood,
But to the virgin comes, who all this while
And heauenly virgin thus outraged see,
There find the virgin dolefull desolate,
The gentle virgin left behind alone
Faire virgin to redeeme her deare
The royall Virgin, which beheld from farre,
What hath poore Virgin for such perill past,
Faire virgin (said the Prince) ye me require
O fairest virgin, full of heauenly light,
Most vertuous virgin borne of heauenly berth,
To aide a virgin desolate foredonne.
Vp rose the gentle virgin from her place,
There this faire virgin wearie of her way
Vntill they came, where that faire virgin stood;
Layd first his filthy hands on virgin cleene,
As a chast Virgin, that wronged beene:
Great and most glorious virgin Queene aliue,
Then taking Congï¿½ fÂ© of that virgin pure,
Alma she called was, a virgin bright;
But the sad virgin innocent of all,
There Alma like a virgin Queene most bright,
The noble virgin, Ladie of the place,
When forth from virgin bowre she comes in th'early morne.
Ah see the Virgin Rose, how sweetly shee
And fell intent against the virgin sheene:
Of the sicke virgin, that her downe she layd
She to the virgin said, thrise said she it;
Sith a sore euill, which this virgin bright
Most noble Virgin, that by fatall lore
Then shall a royall virgin raine, which shall
I saw a Saxon Virgin, the which feld
Thus when she had the virgin all arayd,
A virgin strange and stout him should dismay, or kill.
Most sacred virgin, without spot of sin.
The bountiest virgin, and most debonaire,
Of this faire virgin, this Belphoebe faire,
So was this virgin borne, so was she bred,
With silly Virgin by aduenture brought
But the faire Virgin was so meeke and mild,
The golden ribband, which that virgin wore
But a faire virgin, that in martiall law,
And virgin wex, that neuer yet was seald,
The silly virgin stroue him to withstand,
The virgin, whom he had abusde so sore:
Most vertuous virgin, glory be thy meed,
Which the bold Virgin seeing, gan apply
Soone as that virgin knight he saw in place,
Exceeding wroth therewith the virgin grew,
And chalenging the Virgin as his dew.
To know, what Virgin did them thence vnbind;
Vpon a recluse Virgin to lay hold,
So home with her she streight the virgin lad,
And is the Virgin, sixt in her degree,
Magnificke Virgin, that in queint disguise
Of chastitie and honour virginall:
She to them made, with mildnesse virginall,
Of chastity and vertue virginall,
Then to be false in loue, profest a virgine wife.
The warlike virgine seeing his so prowd
Or fruitfullest Virginia who did euer vew?
Fidelia and Speranza virgins were,
Loe two most goodly virgins came in place,
Abet that virgins cause disconsolate,
The comely virgins came, with girlands dight,
Transformd her to a stone from stedfast virgins state.
That pitty did the Virgins hart of patience rob.
That horror gan the virgins hart to perse,
Of that same wicked Carle, by Virgins hond;
By virgins, and her sacrifices let to rest.
That Virgins loue to win by wit or wile,
A beuie of faire Virgins clad in white,
Her loathly visage viewing with disdaine,
Her from her Palfrey pluckt, her visage to behold.
Where griesly Night, with visage deadly sad,
And sad to view his visage pale and wan,
Thus as he spake, his visage wexed pale,
But hid her visage, and her head downe bent,
So when her goodly visage he beheld,
Of that most glorious visage ye did vew?
Vntill a nation straung, with visage swart,
With hoarie lockes all loose, and visage grim;
And so did let her goodly visage to appere.
And thinke of that faire visage, written in her hart.
But euer when his visage she beheld,
